items.text: Ensure ADDS domain controller(s) are deployed in the identity subscription in native Azure
Ensure ADDS sites and services is configured to keep authentication requests from Azure-based resources (including Azure VMware Solution) local to Azure
Ensure that vCenter is connected to ADDS to enable authentication based on 'named user accounts'
Ensure that the connection from vCenter to ADDS is using a secure protocol (LDAPS)
CloudAdmin account in vCenter IdP is used only as an emergency account (break-glass)
Ensure that NSX-Manager is  integrated with an external Identity provider
Has an RBAC model been created for use within VMware vSphere
RBAC permissions should be granted on ADDS groups and not on specific users
RBAC permissions on the Azure VMware Solution resource in Azure are 'locked down' to a limited set of owners only
Is the correct Azure VMware Solution connectivity model selected for the customer use case at hand
Ensure ExpressRoute or VPN connections from on-premises to Azure are monitored using 'connection monitor'
Ensure a connection monitor is created from an Azure native resource to an Azure VMware Solution virtual machine to monitor the Azure VMware Solution back-end ExpressRoute connection
Ensure a connection monitor is created from an on-premises resource to an Azure VMware Solution virtual machine to monitor end-2-end connectivity
When route server is used, ensure no more then 200 routes are propagated from route server to ExR gateway to on-premises (ARS limit). Important when using MoN
Is Privileged Identity Management implemented for roles managing the Azure VMware Solution resource in the Azure Portal (no standing permissions allowed)
Is Privileged Identity Management audit reporting implemented for the Azure VMware Solution PIM roles
Limit use of CloudAdmin account to emergency access only
Create custom RBAC roles in vCenter to implement a least-privilege model inside vCenter
Is a process defined to regularly rotate cloudadmin (vCenter) and admin (NSX) credentials
Use a centralized identity provider to be used for workloads (VM's) running on Azure VMware Solution
Is East-West traffic filtering implemented within NSX-T
Workloads on Azure VMware Solution are not directly exposed to the internet. Traffic is filtered and inspected by Azure Application Gateway, Azure Firewall or 3rd party solutions
Auditing and logging is implemented for inbound internet requests to Azure VMware Solution and Azure VMware Solution based workloads
Session monitoring is implemented for outbound internet connections from Azure VMware Solution or Azure VMware Solution based workloads to identify suspicious/malicious activity
Is DDoS standard protection enabled on ExR/VPN Gateway subnet in Azure
Use a dedicated privileged access workstation (PAW) to manage Azure VMware Solution, vCenter, NSX manager and HCX manager
Enable Advanced Threat Detection (Microsoft Defender for Cloud aka ASC) for workloads running on Azure VMware Solution
Use Azure ARC for Servers to properly govern workloads running on Azure VMware Solution using Azure native technologies (Azure ARC for Azure VMware Solution is not yet available)
Ensure workloads on Azure VMware Solution use sufficient data encryption during run-time (like in-guest disk encryption and SQL TDE). (vSAN encryption at rest is default)
When in-guest encryption is used, store encryption keys in Azure Key vault when possible
Ensure extended security update support is configured for workloads running on Azure VMware Solution (Azure VMware Solution is eligible for ESU)
Ensure that the appropriate VM template storage policy is used
Ensure that you have requested enough quota, ensuring you have considered growth and Disaster Recovery requirement
Ensure that the Failure-to-tolerate policy is in place to meet your vSAN storage needs
Ensure that access constraints to ESXi are understood, there are access limits which might affect 3rd party solutions.
Ensure that you have a policy around ESXi host density and efficiency, keeping in mind the lead time for requesting new nodes
Ensure a good cost management process is in place for Azure VMware Solution - Azure Cost Management can be used
Are Azure reserved instances used to optimize cost for using Azure VMware Solution
Consider the use of Azure Private-Link when using other Azure Native Services
Enable Microsoft Defender for Cloud for Azure VMware Solution guest VM workloads
Use Azure Arc enabled servers to manage your Azure VMware Solution guest VM workloads
Enable Diagnostic and metric logging on Azure VMware Solution
Deploy the Log Analytics Agents to Azure VMware Solution guest VM workloads
Ensure you have a documented and implemented backup policy and solution for Azure VMware Solution VM workloads
Use Microsoft Defender for Cloud for compliance monitoring of workloads running on Azure VMware Solution
Are the applicable compliance baselines added to Microsoft Defender for Cloud
Was data residency evaluated when selecting Azure regions to use for Azure VMware Solution deployment
Are data processing implications (service provider / service consumer model) clear and documented
Create dashboards to enable core Azure VMware Solution monitoring insights
Create warning alerts for critical thresholds for automatic alerting on Azure VMware Solution performance (CPU >80%, Avg Memory >80%, vSAN >70%)
Ensure critical alert is created to monitor if vSAN consumption is below 75% as this is a support threshold from VMware
Ensure alerts are configured for Azure Service Health alerts and notifications
Configure Azure VMware Solution logging to be send to an Azure Storage account or Azure EventHub for processing
If deep insight in VMware vSphere is required: Is vRealize Operations and/or vRealize Network Insights used in the solution?
Ensure the vSAN storage policy for VM's is NOT the default storage policy as this policy applies thick provisioning
Ensure vSphere content libraries are not placed on vSAN as vSAN is a finite resource
Ensure data repositories for the backup solution are stored outside of vSAN storage. Either in Azure native or on a disk pool-backed datastore
Ensure workloads running on Azure VMware Solution are hybrid managed using Azure Arc for Servers (Arc for Azure VMware Solution is in preview)
Ensure workloads running on Azure VMware Solution are monitored using Azure Log Analytics and Azure Monitor
Include workloads running on Azure VMware Solution in existing update management tooling or in Azure Update Management
Use Azure Policy to onboard Azure VMware Solution workloads in the Azure Management, Monitoring and Security solutions
When ANF is used to extend storage for Azure VMware Solution, ensure it is used at the VM level only for now (ANF as NFS datastore is still in private preview)
Ensure workloads running on Azure VMware Solution are onboarded to Microsoft Defender for Cloud
Ensure backups are not stored on vSAN as vSAN is a finite resource
Use VMware Site Recovery Manager when both sites are Azure VMware Solution
Use Azure Site Recovery when the Disaster Recovery technology is native Azure IaaS
Use Automated recovery plans with either of the Disaster solutions, avoid manual tasks as much as possible
Use the geopolitical region pair as the secondary disaster recovery environment
Use 2 different address spaces between the regions, for example: 10.0.0.0/16 and 192.168.0.0/16 for the different regions
Will ExpressRoute Global Reach be used for connectivity between the primary and secondary Azure VMware Solution Private Clouds or is routing done through network virtual appliances?
Use MABS as your backup solution
Deploy your backup solution in the same region as your Azure VMware Solution private cloud
Preferably deploy MABS outside of the SDDC as native Azure IaaS
Is a process in place to request a restore of the VMware components managed by the Azure Platform?
For manual deployments, all configuration and deployments must be documented
For manual deployments, consider implementing resource locks to prevent accidental actions on your Azure VMware Solution Private Cloud
For automated deployments, deploy a minimal private cloud and scale as needed
For automated deployments,  request or reserve quota prior to starting the deployment
For automated deployment, ensure that relevant resource locks are created through the automation or through Azure Policy for proper governance
Implement human understandable names for ExR authorization keys to allow for easy identification of the keys purpose/use
Use Key vault to store secrets and authorization keys when separate Service Principles are used for deploying Azure VMware Solution and ExpressRoute

Define resource dependencies for serializing actions in IaC when many resources need to be deployed in/on Azure VMware Solution as Azure VMware Solution only supports a limited number of parallel operations.
When performing automated configuration of NSX-T segments with a single Tier-1 gateway, use Azure Portal APIs instead of NSX-Manager APIs
When intending to use automated scale-out, be sure to apply for sufficient Azure VMware Solution quota for the subscriptions running Azure VMware Solution
When intending to use automated scale-in, be sure to take storage policy requirements into account before performing such action
Scaling operations always need to be serialized within a single SDDC as only one scale operation can be performed at a time (even when multiple clusters are used)
Consider and validate scaling operations on 3rd party solutions used in the architecture (supported or not)
Define and enforce scale in/out maximum limits for your environment in the automations
Implement monitoring rules to monitor automated scaling operations and monitor success and failure to enable appropriate (automated) responses
